content: tiny chook by eva mcdonald mclovin this tiny chicken can be used as an ornament or pet toy the base is knitted back and forth then stitches are picked up around the base and joined in the round i used worsted weight with 4 25 mm needles for a 3 5 toy but any weight yarn can be used as long as you go down a needle size to ensure that the fabric is dense so the stuffing does not show through yarn colours - white - red - yellow other materials - 2 double pointed needles for making i-cord - toy stuffing such as polyester fibre fill abbreviations kfb = knit in front & back of same stitch b&t = bind and tie cut yarn run yarn through live stitches and tighten to bind off body with white yarn co 6 sts 1 purl on ws 2 kfb to end of row 12 sts 3 purl on ws 4-17 make stocking stitch knit on rs purl on ws 18 k2tog to end of row 6 sts 19 purl on ws cast off do not break yarn pick up 36 sts around the base as follows 6 sts at each short side and 12 sts along each long side on the long sides pick up 3 out of every 4 sts i e pick up 3 sts skip 1 and repeat join for working in the round the start of the round is in the middle of a short side 1-12 knit starting at the beginning of the round fold piece in half and graft 24 sts together alternately you can turn the piece inside-out and do a 3-needle bind off on 24 sts 12 sts on each side switch to red yarn and knit the remaining 12 live stitches join in the round 1-6 knit stuff the body and head 7 k1 k2tog around 8 sts b&t comb with red yarn co 8 sts 1 purl on ws 2 k2tog yo to end of row 3 purl on ws 4 knit cast off in purl fold piece in half with knit side outward and sew comb into place beak with yellow yarn and dpns co 3 sts alternatively you can pick up 3 sts right on the head make 2 row of i-cord b&t sew beak to the head
